sub_topic: Finding the perimeter of triangles using trigonometry
message_1: A right triangle has a hypotenuse of 13 cm and an opposite side of 5 cm. Find the perimeter of the triangle using trigonometry.
message_2:
To find the perimeter of the triangle, we need to find the length of the third side (the adjacent side) and then add the lengths of all three sides together.

We can use the Pythagorean theorem to find the length of the adjacent side, since we have a right triangle with a hypotenuse of 13 cm and an opposite side of 5 cm. The Pythagorean theorem states that in a right triangle, the square of the length of the hypotenuse (c) is equal to the sum of the squares of the lengths of the other two sides (a and b):

c² = a² + b²

In this case, we have:

13² = 5² + b²
169 = 25 + b²
144 = b²
b = √144
b = 12 cm

Now that we have the length of the adjacent side (12 cm), we can find the perimeter of the triangle by adding the lengths of all three sides:

Perimeter = Hypotenuse + Opposite side + Adjacent side
Perimeter = 13 cm + 5 cm + 12 cm
Perimeter = 30 cm

The perimeter of the triangle is 30 cm.
